p: GLMMs estimated strong negative effects of PPF dissemination on juvenile mosquito catch ( Table 3; Fig 5A). Compared with baseline values, mean juvenile catch (all species) was estimated to fall by 80.2% (95% CI 76.3%–83.5%) and 92.1% (95% CI 89.9%–94.0%) during, respectively, citywide and focal PPF dissemination. The largest effect estimate was for Ae. albopictus catch, with a 94.1% reduction (95% CI 92.0%–95.6%) during focal dissemination and with negative effects still evident after dissemination stopped (36.2% reduction, 95% CI 18.9%–53.7%) ( Fig 5B). Ae. aegypti mean catch was estimated to fall by 72.7% (95% CI 63.9%–79.4%) and 83.1% (95% CI 74.8%–88.7%) during citywide and focal dissemination, respectively ( Fig 5B); the estimated increase in Ae. aegypti catch after PPF dissemination ( Fig 5B) is driven by four outlier dwellings with a mean monthly catch of 30.2 Ae. aegypti juveniles per SBS (see S2 Fig).
